cards.title: Iranians / How do you feel about the nuclear deal?
cards.rawTitle: How do you feel about the nuclear deal?

item.title: Iranians: how do you feel about the 'landmark' nuclear deal?
item.trailText: If you live in Iran – or are part of the diaspora – we want to hear how the agreement will affect you
item.standFirst:
درباره توافق تاریخی هسته‌ای ایران چه فکر می‌کنید؟

If you live in Iran – or are part of the diaspora – we want to hear how the agreement will affect you
item.body:
A comprehensive deal on Iran’s nuclear programme has been reached, bringing to an end a 12-year standoff that had threatened to trigger a new war in the Middle East, potentially marking the beginning of a new era in relations between Iran and the west.

If you live in Iran or are part of the Iranian diaspora we’d like to hear your feelings on the deal. Is it, as Gholamhossein Karbaschi said, a “new opportunity both for Iran and the world”? Or are you reticent to celebrate just yet?

Related: Iran nuclear deal: political figures react to landmark agreement

What do you think will be the most immediate change to day-to-day life in Iran? How will it affect you personally?

Share your stories

Share your thoughts in words, pictures and videos and we’ll use some of the most interesting contributions in our reporting.

Please note that all relevant contributions will be published on the GuardianWitness site. We understand that there may be cultural considerations in sharing photographs and experiences, so please ensure that the content you upload isn’t considered offensive to anyone in your community.

You can share by clicking on the ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness.

cards.title: New Horizons flyby / Share your best space artwork

item.title: New Horizons flyby: share your photos and artwork
item.trailText: With Nasa’s New Horizons spacecraft encountering Pluto on Tuesday, we’d like to see your photographs and artwork of the planets in our solar system
item.standFirst: With Nasa’s New Horizons spacecraft encountering Pluto on Tuesday, we’d like to see your photographs and artwork of the planets in our solar system
item.body:
Nasa’s Pluto probe is entering a crucial stage in its flyby phase, with its New Horizons spacecraft expecting to gather pictures and scientific data of the dwarf planet, 5 billion kilometres away, on Tuesday.

Related: Pluto: Nasa's New Horizons probe shows dwarf planet bigger than expected

We’d like to see your artwork of Pluto and the other planets, both as you have seen them and how you imagined they looked like before images emerged of them. Maybe you have vivid memories of a school trip to an observatory, or spending clear nights staring into a telescope? Whether you have drawn Pluto, captured the brightness of Venus and Jupiter, spotted Mercury at dawn or Saturn in the night sky, share your artwork and photographs of the planets with us. We’ll feature the best of them on the site.

You can share your views by clicking on the ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness.

cards.title: Cities / Which urban views do you cherish?
cards.rawTitle: Which urban views do you cherish?

item.title: Which urban views would you protect?
item.trailText: From Edinburgh to Vancouver, some cities shape development and preserve heritage through the use of protected key vistas. But which are your favourite city views and why? Share your photographs with GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: From Edinburgh to Vancouver, some cities shape development and preserve heritage through the use of protected key vistas. But which are your favourite city views and why? Share your photographs with GuardianWitness
item.body:
Edinburgh’s skyline is maintained through the preservation of key views, Vancouver has protected view corridors and London’s policy includes a view management framework with 27 protected and strategic vistas. Preserved views hope to protect important, historic and well-loved sights of cities – and in the process, shape their development and identity.

These protected views are determined by city authorities, but we want to hear from you: what views in your city do you think should be preserved? What do they show and why do you love them? Wherever you are in the world, share your photos and stories of your favourite city views with GuardianWitness and we’ll feature a selection on Guardian Cities.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.
  • Follow Guardian Cities on Twitter and Facebook and join the discussion

headerImage.caption: Views of Edinburgh castle are protected. Photograph: Murdo MacLeod
headerImage.cleanCaption: Views of Edinburgh castle are protected.

cards.title: Snow in Australia / Share your photos and stories with us
cards.rawTitle: Share your photos and stories with us

item.title: Snow in Australia: share your photos and stories with us
item.trailText: Have you been affected by the unusual cold snap over eastern Australia? If so we’d like to hear from you
item.standFirst: Have you been affected by the unusual cold snap over eastern Australia? If so we’d like to hear from you
item.body:
Queensland experienced its first snow in two years at Eukey, south of Stanthorpe, near the New South Wales border on Monday, with a new cold front expected to bring 5-10cm of snow on Tuesday.

Are you enjoying the snow? Perhaps travel arrangements have been affected near where you live? Share your photos, videos and stories with us and we’ll feature the most interesting contributions on the site.

You can share your views by clicking on the ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness.

This article was amended on Tuesday 14 July to correct the amount of snow expected to fall.

cards.title: Housing crisis / What would make London a fairer city?
cards.rawTitle: What would make London a fairer city?

item.title: What would make London a fairer city?
item.trailText: A glittering global capital that attracts investment and an emblem of a housing crisis with a quarter of residents living in poverty. Is London fair? The London Fairness Commission wants to hear your thoughts on what would make it better
item.standFirst: A glittering global capital that attracts investment and an emblem of a housing crisis with a quarter of residents living in poverty. Is London fair? The London Fairness Commission wants to hear your thoughts on what would make it better
item.body:
Transport delays, rainy days and noisy neighbours: if you’re a Londoner, lots of daily irritations might feel unfair. But when we really think of what fairness means, is London a fair city?

Inequality grips the UK capital: while many benefit from the city’s economic successes, others struggle to get by. As a housing crisis causes many to live in poor conditions or move out of the city altogether, construction cranes animate our skyline to build yet more luxury developments. In 2013, the London Poverty Profile reported that more than a quarter of Londoners (28%) were living in poverty, and that the city is the most unequal region in the country in terms of income.

But, as Danny Dorling and Richard Brooks outline, fairness is far more than just equality. The London Fairness Commission, for which they are both commissioners, was launched last month to start conversations ahead of the 2016 Mayoral election about whether London is a fair city, and if not, how it could become fairer.

“Rather than advocating for our own interpretation of fairness in London, we want to hear how Londoners understand fairness and which measures they feel are needed to make London the leading global fair city,” Dorling and Brooks explain. To this end, the commission is undertaking a callout to gather responses from Londoners on the topic which will help inform the solutions the commission presents to the Mayoral candidates next year.

The Commission is chaired by Lord Victor Adebowale, and is comprised of fourteen expert commissioners from across the worlds of business, research, health and charity. The considerations of the Commission will be structured around the themes of income, wealth and housing.

Share your thoughts and priorities on making London a fair city below – and we will feature a selection of responses on Guardian Cities. The call for responses closes on 1 August 2015.

displayImages.altText: Cranes around St.Paul's Cathedral in London.

cards.title: Housing / What have been your experiences of renting in London?
cards.rawTitle: What have been your experiences of renting in London?

item.title: What are your experiences of renting in London?
item.trailText: Rental prices in London are rising five times faster than tenant pay. What are your experiences of being a private tenant in the capital?
item.standFirst: With rental prices in London rising five times faster than tenant pay, we want to hear your experiences of renting in the capital
item.body:
Private renters in London face soaring costs with the shortage in housing, and a host of other factors, pushing up prices everywhere. Renters find it difficult to get on the ladder and workers are pushed further and further from the centre of the capital.

In the three months prior to June rental prices rose five times faster than the average tenant income, according to the Office of National Statistics.

As the shortage of housing causes prices to spiral out-of-control, unconventional living arrangements emerge. Room-sharing with strangers, for example, is on the rise and increasing numbers of 20-to 45-year-olds are moving back in with their parents.

So what’s your experience of renting in London?

Have you seen your rent go up by exorbitant levels mid contract? Are you one of those who has moved back with your parents because you can’t afford rent?

Perhaps you are one of the many divorcees in their 30s or 40s or key workers who just find it difficult to live in London because of the accommodation expenses.

We want to hear from you. Share your story by filling in the form below. We’ll use a selection in a feature on the London rental crisis.

displayImages.altText: Demonstrators wearing WWII uniforms protest at a Homes for Britain rally in London, calling for political parties to end the crisis within a generation

displayImages.caption:
Summer fun at Lossiemouth
A incredibly sunny day in the far NE of Scotland at Lossiemouth , all were out to enjoy the the wonderful summers day. I spotted this family playing in the river below the bridge just before you reach East beach. The sun beat down on them but nothing detered them from enjoying the heat and the chance to padle in the river Lossie
Photograph: Ruth Grindrod/GuardianWitness
